story.iWant: To measure caller learning modality preferences using the VARK model
story.soThat: I can adapt my teaching style to match each learner's preferred information processing mode

context.applies: All learning-oriented conversations - modality assessment runs continuously
assumptions: Sufficient conversational turns to establish modality patterns
Caller is speaking naturally about learning topics
Modality preferences are stable but context-dependent
Most learners are multimodal with varying strengths

acceptanceCriteria.title: Visual modality detection
acceptanceCriteria.given: A caller engaged in learning conversation
acceptanceCriteria.when: The system analyzes spatial language and visualization requests
acceptanceCriteria.then: A Visual modality score between 0-1 is produced
acceptanceCriteria.rationale: Visual learners process information best through mental imagery and spatial relationships

acceptanceCriteria.title: Auditory modality detection
acceptanceCriteria.given: A caller engaged in learning conversation
acceptanceCriteria.when: The system analyzes verbal processing patterns and sound-based language
acceptanceCriteria.then: An Auditory modality score between 0-1 is produced
acceptanceCriteria.rationale: Auditory learners process information best through verbal explanation and discussion

acceptanceCriteria.title: Reading/Writing modality detection
acceptanceCriteria.given: A caller engaged in learning conversation
acceptanceCriteria.when: The system analyzes text-oriented language and structured thinking patterns
acceptanceCriteria.then: A Reading/Writing modality score between 0-1 is produced
acceptanceCriteria.rationale: Read/Write learners process information best through written words and structured text

acceptanceCriteria.title: Kinesthetic modality detection
acceptanceCriteria.given: A caller engaged in learning conversation
acceptanceCriteria.when: The system analyzes experiential language and action-oriented requests
acceptanceCriteria.then: A Kinesthetic modality score between 0-1 is produced
acceptanceCriteria.rationale: Kinesthetic learners process information best through physical experience and practice

acceptanceCriteria.title: Multimodal profile computation
acceptanceCriteria.given: All four modality scores have been computed
acceptanceCriteria.when: The system determines the caller's modality profile
acceptanceCriteria.then: A multimodal classification is produced (unimodal, bimodal, trimodal, or quadmodal)
acceptanceCriteria.rationale: Most learners have multiple strong modalities; knowing the combination guides adaptation

constraints.description: VARK scores should correlate with validated VARK questionnaire at r >= 0.55
Modality scores should stabilize after 5-7 learning interactions and not fluctuate wildly
VARK scores are relative strengths, not absolute - at least one modality should be >= 0.5
Modality preferences may shift by topic domain - track domain-specific patterns when possible

failureConditions.implication: Not enough learning interactions to assess modality - use balanced multimodal approach
No clear modality preference detected - may indicate non-learning conversation

parameters.name: visual_modality
parameters.description: Visual learning preference - processing information through mental imagery, spatial relationships, diagrams, and visual metaphors

subMetrics.name: Visual Language Use
subMetrics.description: Frequency of sight-based and visual metaphor language

definitions.low: Rarely uses visual language; prefers other sensory or abstract terms

markers: I need to see the big picture
Looking at it from this angle

subMetrics.name: Spatial Reasoning Expression
subMetrics.description: Use of spatial relationships and structural language

definitions.high: Organizes concepts spatially; uses 'above', 'below', 'connected to', 'flows from'

markers: The flow goes from X to Y

subMetrics.name: Visualization Requests
subMetrics.description: Explicit requests for visual aids or mental imagery

definitions.high: Asks for diagrams, charts, or verbal picture-painting; wants to 'see' the concept
definitions.low: Doesn't request visual representations; satisfied with verbal or written explanation

markers: Can you draw me a picture of
Is there a diagram for this
Can you paint a mental picture
If I were to diagram this

subMetrics.name: Imagery Engagement
subMetrics.description: Responsiveness to visual descriptions and metaphors

definitions.high: Lights up when given visual examples; extends visual metaphors; says 'I can see that now'
definitions.low: Visual descriptions don't resonate; may ask for different explanation type

interpretationScale.label: Low Visual
interpretationScale.implication: Visual approaches unlikely to resonate - use other modalities

interpretationScale.label: Mild Visual
interpretationScale.implication: Some visual elements helpful but not primary learning mode

interpretationScale.label: Moderate Visual
interpretationScale.implication: Visual learning is significant - include mental imagery and spatial organization

interpretationScale.label: Strong Visual
interpretationScale.implication: Visual learning is dominant - paint mental pictures, use spatial metaphors

interpretationScale.label: Highly Visual
interpretationScale.implication: Visual processing is primary mode - structure everything spatially with vivid imagery

scoringAnchors.example: Just explain it to me. I don't need to picture anything, I just want to understand the logic.
scoringAnchors.rationale: Explicitly rejects visual framing; wants logical/verbal explanation instead

scoringAnchors.example: Okay, I think I follow. You could maybe give me an example?
scoringAnchors.rationale: Wants concrete example but doesn't specifically request visual framing

scoringAnchors.example: I see what you mean - so if I picture it like a tree structure, the branches would be the different options?
scoringAnchors.rationale: Uses visual language naturally; creates own spatial metaphor to organize concepts

scoringAnchors.example: Can you help me visualize this? I'm trying to picture how all the pieces fit together. Like, if I were looking at a map of this concept...
scoringAnchors.rationale: Explicitly requests visualization; naturally thinks in spatial/visual terms

scoringAnchors.example: Oh! Now I can see it clearly - it's like a web with the main idea in the center and everything else radiating out. The connections are so obvious when you look at it this way. Can you describe what the next layer looks like?
scoringAnchors.rationale: Deeply visual processing; constructs elaborate mental imagery; breakthrough comes through visualization

promptGuidance.whenHigh: This learner is highly visual. Paint vivid mental pictures: 'Imagine you're looking at...' Use spatial metaphors extensively. Describe concepts as landscapes, structures, or diagrams. Say 'picture this' and 'from this perspective'. Organize information as mental maps or flowcharts.
promptGuidance.whenLow: This learner doesn't rely on visual processing. Don't force visual metaphors. Use logical explanations, verbal reasoning, or hands-on examples instead.
promptGuidance.whenMedium: Include some visual elements and spatial organization, but balance with other approaches. Offer to 'paint a picture' if helpful.
promptGuidance.promptTemplate: {{#if (gte visual_modality 0.65)}}Paint mental pictures for this visual learner. Use phrases like 'imagine you can see...' and organize concepts spatially. Describe relationships as visual structures.{{else if (lte visual_modality 0.3)}}This learner doesn't process visually - focus on verbal explanation or hands-on examples instead.{{/if}}

parameters.name: auditory_modality
parameters.description: Auditory learning preference - processing information through listening, verbal discussion, rhythm, and sound-based language

subMetrics.name: Auditory Language Use
subMetrics.description: Frequency of sound-based and auditory metaphor language

definitions.high: Uses 'sounds like', 'I hear you', 'that rings true', 'tell me', 'listen'
definitions.low: Rarely uses auditory language; prefers visual or action-based terms

markers: Something about that doesn't sound right

subMetrics.name: Verbal Processing Style
subMetrics.description: Preference for talking through problems and verbal rehearsal

definitions.high: Talks through problems aloud; verbal rehearsal; thinks by speaking
definitions.low: Processes internally; may find excessive verbalization distracting

markers: So if I say this back to you
I'm just going to talk through this
Bear with me while I work this out verbally
When I explain it to myself
Saying it helps me understand it

subMetrics.name: Discussion Preference
subMetrics.description: Preference for dialogue and verbal exchange over solo processing

definitions.high: Prefers back-and-forth dialogue; asks clarifying questions verbally; learns through conversation
definitions.low: Prefers to read/think independently; may find extended discussion tiring

markers: I'd rather discuss it than read about it
Can you explain it to me
I learn better when we talk about it

subMetrics.name: Verbal Repetition Requests
subMetrics.description: Requests to hear information repeated or rephrased

definitions.high: Frequently asks to hear things again; 'can you say that another way'; values verbal reinforcement
definitions.low: Doesn't need verbal repetition; may prefer written reference

markers: How would you phrase that differently

interpretationScale.label: Low Auditory
interpretationScale.implication: Verbal-heavy teaching may be ineffective - use other modalities

interpretationScale.label: Mild Auditory
interpretationScale.implication: Some verbal explanation helpful but shouldn't be primary mode

interpretationScale.label: Moderate Auditory
interpretationScale.implication: Auditory learning is significant - emphasize verbal discussion

interpretationScale.label: Strong Auditory
interpretationScale.implication: Auditory learning is dominant - use rich verbal elaboration, encourage talk-through

interpretationScale.label: Highly Auditory
interpretationScale.implication: Auditory processing is primary mode - everything through verbal dialogue and sound

scoringAnchors.example: I'd rather just read about it. Can you send me something I can look at later?
scoringAnchors.rationale: Explicitly prefers written over verbal; finds listening less effective

scoringAnchors.example: Sure, keep going. I'm following along.
scoringAnchors.rationale: Accepts verbal explanation but doesn't actively engage auditorily

scoringAnchors.example: That sounds right to me. Let me just say it back to make sure I've got it - so you're saying that...
scoringAnchors.rationale: Uses auditory language; verbal rehearsal to confirm understanding

scoringAnchors.example: Can we just talk through this? I find I understand so much better when I hear it explained and can ask questions. Tell me more about that last part.
scoringAnchors.rationale: Explicitly prefers verbal learning; asks for elaboration; values discussion

scoringAnchors.example: Oh, the way you said that just clicked! Can you say it again exactly like that? I want to hear it a few times so it really sinks in. Something about the rhythm of how you explained it makes it so much clearer.
scoringAnchors.rationale: Deep auditory processing; repetition important; notices rhythm/cadence of explanation

promptGuidance.whenHigh: This learner is highly auditory. Emphasize verbal explanation with rich elaboration. Encourage them to 'talk through' their understanding. Use phrases like 'let me tell you about' and 'does this sound right?' Rhythm and cadence of explanation matter. Offer to repeat key points.
promptGuidance.whenLow: This learner doesn't prefer auditory processing. Keep verbal explanations concise. Offer written or visual alternatives. Don't rely on verbal repetition for reinforcement.
promptGuidance.whenMedium: Balance verbal explanation with other modalities. Some discussion and verbal elaboration, but don't make it the only approach.
promptGuidance.promptTemplate: {{#if (gte auditory_modality 0.65)}}Use rich verbal elaboration with this auditory learner. Encourage them to talk through their understanding. Ask 'does this sound right?' and offer to repeat key points.{{else if (lte auditory_modality 0.3)}}Keep verbal explanations concise - this learner prefers other modalities.{{/if}}

parameters.name: reading_writing_modality
parameters.description: Reading/Writing learning preference - processing information through written text, lists, definitions, and structured prose

subMetrics.name: Text Orientation
subMetrics.description: Preference for written words and text-based sources

definitions.high: References books, articles, written sources; asks for text resources; values the written word
definitions.low: Prefers verbal explanation or experiential learning over reading

markers: Is there an article about this
I'd like to read more about
Where can I find this written down

subMetrics.name: Definition Seeking
subMetrics.description: Desire for precise definitions and terminology

definitions.high: Asks 'what exactly does X mean?'; wants precise terminology; values formal definitions
definitions.low: Comfortable with approximate understanding; doesn't need formal definitions

markers: What exactly do you mean by
Is there a technical term for
Can you be more specific about what X means

subMetrics.name: Structured Expression
subMetrics.description: Use of lists, bullet points, and organized verbal structure

definitions.high: Speaks in lists ('first... second... third'); organizes thoughts hierarchically; uses ordinals
definitions.low: Speaks in unstructured, flowing narrative; doesn't enumerate

subMetrics.name: Note-Taking Signals
subMetrics.description: Indicators of mental or actual note-taking during learning

definitions.high: Pauses to 'write that down'; asks for spelling; wants key points summarized
definitions.low: Doesn't pause for note-taking; processes without writing things down

markers: What were the key points again
I want to jot this down
Hold on, let me get that

interpretationScale.label: Low Read/Write
interpretationScale.implication: Text-heavy teaching unlikely to resonate - use verbal or experiential

interpretationScale.label: Mild Read/Write
interpretationScale.implication: Some text reference helpful but shouldn't be primary mode

interpretationScale.label: Moderate Read/Write
interpretationScale.implication: Read/Write learning is significant - provide structured summaries and definitions

interpretationScale.label: Strong Read/Write
interpretationScale.implication: Read/Write learning is dominant - use precise terminology, lists, structured explanations

interpretationScale.label: Highly Read/Write
interpretationScale.implication: Text-based processing is primary mode - structure everything as organized prose/lists

scoringAnchors.example: I don't want to read a bunch of stuff. Can you just explain it to me or show me how to do it?
scoringAnchors.rationale: Explicitly rejects text-based learning; prefers verbal or experiential

scoringAnchors.example: Sure, I could look at an article about it, but honestly I'd rather just talk it through.
scoringAnchors.rationale: Open to text but not preferred; verbal learning more natural

scoringAnchors.example: That's helpful. Can you give me a quick summary of the main points? I want to make sure I've got them written down correctly.
scoringAnchors.rationale: Wants structured summary; taking notes; values written record

scoringAnchors.example: What's the formal definition of that term? I want to make sure I understand exactly what it means. And is there a book or article you'd recommend where I can read more?
scoringAnchors.rationale: Seeks precise definitions; references text sources; values formal terminology

scoringAnchors.example: Let me organize this. So there are three main concepts: first, [X], which is defined as... second, [Y], meaning... and third, [Z]. Is that the right structure? I like to have it written out systematically before I really feel like I understand it.
scoringAnchors.rationale: Deep read/write processing; creates structured lists; needs organized text representation to learn

promptGuidance.whenHigh: This learner is highly text-oriented. Provide precise definitions and formal terminology. Structure explanations as lists with clear hierarchies. Offer summaries and key points. Use phrases like 'to define this precisely' and 'the three main elements are'. Recommend reading resources.
promptGuidance.whenLow: This learner doesn't prefer text-based processing. Don't overwhelm with lists or formal definitions. Use conversational explanation or experiential examples.
promptGuidance.whenMedium: Provide some structure and definitions, but balance with verbal and experiential elements. Offer to summarize key points.
promptGuidance.promptTemplate: {{#if (gte reading_writing_modality 0.65)}}Use precise definitions and structured lists with this Read/Write learner. Organize information hierarchically. Offer summaries and recommend reading resources.{{else if (lte reading_writing_modality 0.3)}}Keep it conversational - this learner doesn't need formal definitions or extensive text structure.{{/if}}

parameters.name: kinesthetic_modality
parameters.description: Kinesthetic learning preference - processing information through physical experience, practice, emotions, and embodied understanding

subMetrics.name: Experiential Language Use
subMetrics.description: Frequency of touch, feel, and physical experience language

definitions.high: Uses 'I feel', 'that hits home', 'grasp this', 'get a handle on', 'hands-on'
definitions.low: Rarely uses physical/feeling language; prefers abstract or sensory-specific terms

markers: I need to get a handle on this
I'm struggling to hold onto this concept
I want to get my hands on
This is hard to wrap my head around

subMetrics.name: Action Orientation
subMetrics.description: Preference for doing, trying, and active engagement

definitions.high: Wants to 'try it out', 'do something', 'practice'; prefers action over passive learning
definitions.low: Comfortable with passive reception; doesn't need to 'do' to learn

markers: Show me so I can try
I won't really get it until I do it

subMetrics.name: Feeling/Emotion References
subMetrics.description: Connection of learning to emotional or gut-level understanding

definitions.high: References how things 'feel'; gut reactions; emotional connection to learning
definitions.low: Focuses on logical understanding without emotional/feeling component

markers: I feel like I'm getting it
That doesn't sit right with me

subMetrics.name: Practice/Application Requests
subMetrics.description: Requests for practical application, exercises, or real-world examples

definitions.high: Asks 'how do I use this?', wants practice problems, real-world applications
definitions.low: Satisfied with theoretical understanding; doesn't need practice

markers: Can you give me a practice problem
What does this look like in real life
I need to work through an example
Let me try with a real case
When would I actually use this

interpretationScale.label: Low Kinesthetic
interpretationScale.implication: Experiential approaches may not be necessary - theoretical explanation works

interpretationScale.label: Mild Kinesthetic
interpretationScale.implication: Some practical application helpful but not primary learning mode

interpretationScale.label: Moderate Kinesthetic
interpretationScale.implication: Kinesthetic learning is significant - include practice and real-world examples

interpretationScale.label: Strong Kinesthetic
interpretationScale.implication: Kinesthetic learning is dominant - ground in experience and action

interpretationScale.label: Highly Kinesthetic
interpretationScale.implication: Experiential processing is primary mode - everything through doing and feeling

scoringAnchors.example: I don't need to practice it. Just explain the concept and I'll understand the theory.
scoringAnchors.rationale: Explicitly doesn't need experiential learning; comfortable with abstract understanding

scoringAnchors.example: I think I understand. Maybe I'll try it out later, but for now the explanation is enough.
scoringAnchors.rationale: Open to practice eventually but doesn't need it to learn; theory-first approach

scoringAnchors.example: Okay, that makes sense. But can you give me a real example I can work through? I want to feel like I can actually do this.
scoringAnchors.rationale: Wants practical application; uses feeling language; needs to 'do' to internalize

scoringAnchors.example: I really need to try this myself. I learn by doing, not by listening. Can we work through a hands-on example together? I won't really get it until I feel it click.
scoringAnchors.rationale: Explicitly kinesthetic; action-oriented; feeling-based understanding

scoringAnchors.example: Let me just dive in and try it. I know I'll make mistakes but that's how I learn - I need to feel my way through it. The theory doesn't land for me until I've gotten my hands dirty and experienced what works and what doesn't. Can we do something active?
scoringAnchors.rationale: Deep kinesthetic processing; learns through trial and physical/emotional experience; needs action

promptGuidance.whenHigh: This learner is highly kinesthetic. Ground everything in practical application and real-world examples. Use action verbs and physical metaphors. Ask 'how does that feel?' Connect concepts to bodily or emotional experience. Offer practice exercises and simulated scenarios.
promptGuidance.whenLow: This learner doesn't need experiential learning. Theoretical explanation is effective. Don't force action-oriented approaches if they're comfortable with abstraction.
promptGuidance.whenMedium: Include practical examples and some hands-on elements, but balance with other modalities. Offer to work through applications when it would help.
promptGuidance.promptTemplate: {{#if (gte kinesthetic_modality 0.65)}}Use action and experience with this kinesthetic learner. Ground concepts in practical application. Ask 'how does that feel?' Use physical metaphors and offer practice exercises.{{else if (lte kinesthetic_modality 0.3)}}Theoretical explanation works well - this learner doesn't need extensive practice to understand.{{/if}}

parameters.name: multimodal_profile
parameters.description: Classification of learner's multimodal profile based on relative strengths across all four modalities

interpretationScale.label: Unimodal
interpretationScale.implication: Single dominant modality - strongly favor that approach

interpretationScale.label: Bimodal
interpretationScale.implication: Two strong modalities - blend both approaches

interpretationScale.label: Trimodal
interpretationScale.implication: Three strong modalities - use multiple approaches

interpretationScale.label: Quadmodal
interpretationScale.implication: All modalities strong - vary approaches freely

scoringAnchors.rationale: Strong single modality (Visual); unimodal profile
Two strong modalities (Visual + Auditory); bimodal VA profile
Three strong modalities (VAR); trimodal profile
All modalities above threshold; quadmodal/Type Two profile

promptGuidance.whenHigh: This learner is multimodal and processes well through multiple channels. Vary your approach - visual metaphors, verbal elaboration, structured summaries, and practical examples. Match the moment.
promptGuidance.whenLow: This learner has a dominant modality. Focus primarily on their strongest channel and use others as supplements.
promptGuidance.whenMedium: Blend 2-3 modalities based on relative strengths. Lead with strongest, support with secondary.
promptGuidance.promptTemplate: {{#if (gte multimodal_profile 0.75)}}This quadmodal learner processes through all channels - vary your approach: visuals, discussion, lists, and practice.{{else if (lte multimodal_profile 0.25)}}This unimodal learner has one clear preference - focus on their dominant modality.{{else}}Blend multiple approaches, leading with strongest modalities.{{/if}}

workedExamples.description: Calculating visual modality for a learner who thinks in spatial metaphors
workedExamples.input: Learner frequently uses phrases like 'I see', 'picture this', asks to visualize connections between concepts, and creates mental maps

finalResult.interpretation: Moderate Visual - include mental imagery and spatial organization

workedExamples.description: Calculating kinesthetic modality for a hands-on learner
workedExamples.input: Learner says 'I learn by doing', asks for practice problems, uses feeling language, and gets frustrated with pure theory

finalResult.interpretation: Strong Kinesthetic - ground in experience and action
